Award.AwardTitle: Modeling the Vegetation of the Past
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project tests a Dynamic Global Vegetation Model (DGVM) using reconstructions of past vegetation for North America and Europe based on paleoecological data. The DGVM is driven by past climate simulated with a fully coupled General Circulation Model (GCM), and the paleovegetation reconstructions are taken from continental scale databases of pollen and plant macrofossil data covering North America and Europe. Past vegetation can also serve as a direct proxy of past climate variations, and recent studies have shown that a DGVM can be used to help interpret the climate signal from pollen and macrofossil data. These techniques allow assessment of the role of non-climatic factors (e.g., CO2) in driving vegetation change. The project is able to identify and reduce bias in climate reconstructions for glacial periods, where these factors are significantly different from the present day.

DGVMs are one of the primary tools used to understand how terrestrial ecosystems might be affected by future climate change under various scenarios. By studying past periods, the predictive ability of these models in simulating ecosystem change under conditions that are different from the present day can be tested. The results from the model runs can also be used to investigate past changes in services provided by terrestrial ecosystems, including carbon sequestration and water resources. The work will also provide an assessment of the GCM used to simulate past climates, which will help to understand its skill in simulating future global change. The project results will include a consistent dataset of environmental conditions covering the last 21000 years. This will be made publicly available at the end of the project, and will provide a context for archeological studies and studies of land-surface history and processes. These results will be transformed into publicly accessible online teaching resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant remains, trapped in sedimentary records extracted from lakes and peat bogs, provide information about past terrestrial ecosystems over hundreds to thousands of years. Our project has used networks of these records over the North American and European continent to examine the spatial pattern of past vegetation how this has changed over time. The results emphasize the individual response of different plant species in response to the climatic changes following the last glacial periods, across many different aspects of vegetation dynamics: the timing of initial and peak spread and the patterns of spread and period of peak area occupied, giving rise to unusual, ‘non-analog’ vegetation types. Identifying the controls on these ecosystem changes is difficult as these past periods featured different climatic (temperature and precipitation) and non-climatic factors (atmospheric CO2, disturbance regimes). We used a process-based dynamic vegetation model to help understand the role of these factors in controlling the observed changes. By varying the different drivers (temperature, precipitation, atmospheric CO2) used in the model, it was possible to show that seasonal temperature was the dominant control on vegetation formations following the last glacial period in North America, with reduced atmospheric CO2 and altered disturbance regimes playing a lesser role.

As the modern distribution of vegetation is largely controlled by climate factors, the same datasets may be used to reconstruct past climate, by estimating how much the climate would have to change in order to obtain the vegetation observed in the sediment records. These results showed a warming, then cooling trend in the north of both continents over the past 12,000 years, with an opposing trend in the south. In addition, significant precipitation variability over North America was shown over, which can be linked to rapid ecosystem changes. The reconstructed climate patterns can be used to test how well general circulation models (GCMs) simulate climate outside of the modern period. A comparison was carried out between our results and simulations from a fully coupled GCM run for the period between the last glacial period and the present day. Temperature trends are well reproduced by the model, but the similarity declines at lower latitudes. This mis-match may be due to a limitation on climate reconstructions in moisture-limited areas, or may indicate an excess sensitivity to high latitude insolation in the models

The results produced in this project are expected to have uses in other fields. Notably, our studies of past vegetation distribution are being used to examine large-scale changes in biodiversity at a continental scale, and may be used in work attempting to quantify the magnitude of past land-use. The estimates of past climate may be more broadly used to test GCMs.
